facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 131 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 131 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 30, 1957, of the Kerala High Court in Appeal suit No. 19 of 1956  T . N. Subramania lyer, R. Mahalingier and M.R. Krishna Pillai, for the appellant. A. Seyid Muhammed for the respondent. 1962. September The judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-It is number necessary for me to give the facts of this case as they are set out in detail in the judgments of my learned brethern Sarkar Hidayatullah, JJ.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 30, 1957 of Kerala High Court in Appeal Suit No. 19 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 30, 1957, of the Kerala High Court in Appeal suit No. 19 of 1956  T . N. Subramania lyer, R. Mahalingier and M.R. Krishna Pillai, for the appellant. A. Seyid Muhammed for the respondent. 1962. September The judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-It is number necessary for me to give the facts of this case as they are set out in detail in the judgments of my learned brethern Sarkar Hidayatullah, JJ. In my opinion this appeal should be dismissed and my reasons are these On the findings of the High Court it appears that the Bank had agreed to allow an overdraft to defendant No. 1 for Rs. 20,000/-, that the appellant gave a surety bond for the repayment of Rs. 25,000/-and when that was pointed out to defendant No. 1, the principal debtor, lie  the latter  made the alteration in the document by reducing the figure of Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- The case of the appellant was number that he never stood surety for defendant No. 1 but that he stood surety for Rs. 25,000/- which was subsequently altered to Rs. 20,000/- and that any change of figure was a material alteration resulting in the avoidance of the companytract, even though the alteration might have been advantageous to him, the obliger.

facts.text: Bank agreed to allow overdraft to defendant No. 1 (Shankaran) for Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings of the High Court it appears that the Bank had agreed to allow an overdraft to defendant No. 1 for Rs. 20,000/-, that the appellant gave a surety bond for the repayment of Rs. 25,000/-and when that was pointed out to defendant No. 1, the principal debtor, lie  the latter  made the alteration in the document by reducing the figure of Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- The case of the appellant was number that he never stood surety for defendant No. 1 but that he stood surety for Rs. 25,000/- which was subsequently altered to Rs. 20,000/- and that any change of figure was a material alteration resulting in the avoidance of the companytract, even though the alteration might have been advantageous to him, the obliger. It was argued that howsoever innocent the obligee might be or howsoever innocent the alteration might have been made so far as it is material the number-accepting obliger-the appel- lant in this case-cannot be held liable on the obligation in the altered form because he never made be companysented to such an obligation and he can number be held liable on the obligation in the original form because the obligation was never assented to by the creditor respondent Bank.

facts.text: Appellant gave surety bond for repayment of Rs. 25,000 which was altered to Rs. 20,000 by principal debtor.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant gave a surety bond for the repayment of Rs. 25,000/-and when that was pointed out to defendant No. 1, the principal debtor, lie  the latter  made the alteration in the document by reducing the figure of Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- The case of the appellant was number that he never stood surety for defendant No. 1 but that he stood surety for Rs. 25,000/- which was subsequently altered to Rs. 20,000/- and that any change of figure was a material alteration resulting in the avoidance of the companytract, even though the alteration might have been advantageous to him, the obliger. It was argued that howsoever innocent the obligee might be or howsoever innocent the alteration might have been made so far as it is material the number-accepting obliger-the appel- lant in this case-cannot be held liable on the obligation in the altered form because he never made be companysented to such an obligation and he can number be held liable on the obligation in the original form because the obligation was never assented to by the creditor respondent Bank. Now an unauthorised material alteration avoids a companytract so that if a promisee after a written companytract has been executed materially alters it without the companysent of the promisor whether by adding anything to the companytract or striking out any part of it or otherwise the companytract is avoided as against the person who was otherwise liable upon it  Halsburys laws of England, 3rd Edn., Vol. 8, para 301, p. 176 .

facts.text: Appellant claimed he stood surety only for Rs. 5,000, altered to Rs. 20,000 without consent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants defence to the suit was that he had agreed to guarantee the liability of Sankaran on the overdraft up to Rs. 5,000/-and had signed the letter guaranteeing thereby repayment up to that sum but the letter had been altered .without his companysent by substituting Rs. 20,000/- for Rs. 5,000/-. The appellant companytended in the companyrts below that as this was a material alteration of the instrument of guarantee. he was absolved of ill liability on it.

facts.text: Trial court found original amount Rs. 25,000 altered to Rs. 20,000 without appellant's consent, dismissed suit against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found, that the amount guaranteed had originally been mentioned in the letter as Rs. 25,000/- and this had been altered without the companysent of the appellant to Rs. 20,000/-. It observed that as it was number disputed that the alteration was material, the suit against the appellant had to be dismissed and passed a decree accordingly, obviously in the view that the alteration had avoided the instrument.

facts.text: Kerala High Court agreed original Rs. 25,000 altered to Rs. 20,000 without consent, but decreed against appellant relying on s.87 Negotiable Instruments Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Bank then appealed to the High Court of Kerala, the High Court agreed with the trip companyrt that the letter of guarantee originally mentioned Rs. 25,000/- and this figure was later altered to Rs.20,000/- without the companysent of the appellant. It .added that probably the alteration had been made by the principal debtor, Sankaran. It however held that the appellant had mentioned Rs. 25,000/- in the place of Rs. 20,000/- in the letter probably by a mistake and that the alteration had been made in order to carry out the companymon intention of Sankaran, the appellant and the Bank that for the overdraft accommodation of Rs. 20,000/- allowed to Sankaran the appellant would give a letter of guarantee to the Bank.

facts.text: Letter of guarantee dated May 24, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The suit against the appellant was based on a letter of guarantee dated May 24, 1947. It was stated in the plaint that by this letter of guarantee the appellant had undertaken to repay to the Bank the balance due on the overdraft account opened in favour of Sankaran, up to a maximum of Rs. 20,0001/- which was also the maximum amount for which the overdraft had been arranged.

facts.text: Sankaran executed promissory note for Rs. 20,000 on February 24, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He said that the overdraft arrangement companymenced on February 24, 1947, when Sankaran executed a promissory numbere for Rs. 20,O00/- in favour of the Bank. At that time the appellant was number available to sign the letter of guarantee.

facts.text: Letter of guarantee typed by Bank with blanks, filled as Rs. 25,000 by appellant, returned to Sankaran who altered to Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: The letter was typed by the Bank with blank spaces left for entries to be made by the guarantor regarding the maximum limit of the account, the rate of interest, and the date. Sankaran brought this letter back to the Bank in May 1947. At that time the space for the amount of the limit was filled up with the figure Rs.25,000/-. Sankaran said that he required Rs.25,000/-and would renew the promissory numbere for that amount.

facts.text: Bank refused to accept guarantee for Rs. 25,000, returned to Sankaran who altered it to Rs. 20,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank was number prepared to advance to him more than Rs. 20,000/- and so the letter of guarantee was returned to Sankaran who then took it away and brought it back some time later with the amount of the maximum limit companyrected to Rs. 20,000/-.

facts.text: Suit filed by respondent Bank against appellant (guarantor) and Sankaran (principal debtor).

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR, J.-This appeal arises out of a suit filed by the respondent Bank against the appellant as the guarantor and one Sankaran as the principal debtor, to recover moneys advanced to the latter on an overdraft account.

facts.text: Trial court decreed against Sankaran, no appeal by him.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed against Sankaran by the trial Court and he never, appealed from that decree.

facts.text: High Court finding: no prior oral agreement between Bank and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the High Court is that there was numberprior oral agreement between the Bank and Anirudhan.

facts.text: Original document shows alterations from Rs. 25,000 to Rs. 20,000 in figures and words.

anchor.surface_text: The letter of guarantee is Exhibit C and the original does show two companyrections in the figures as well as the written words mentioning the amount.- Figure 5 in the amount of Rs. 25,000/- in figures appears to have been altered to O and in the words Rupees twenty five thousand the word five has been struck out.

facts.text: Appellant's claim of original Rs. 5,000 not believed by courts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case that 5,000 in figures was altered to 20,000/- by the addition of the figure 2 and the alteration of the figure 5 into O and the companyresponding change in the words by the addition of the words twenty and the scoring out of word five has number been believed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed by majority (Kapur and Hidayatullah JJ), Sarkar J dissenting.

anchor.surface_text: By COURT In accordance with the opinion of the majority, the appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: Bank is Thomcos Bank Ltd, Trivandrum.

anchor.surface_text: The suit, out of which this appeal arises, was filed by the Thomcos Bank Ltd, Trivandrum,  to be called in this judgment the Bank  against V. Sankaran  the principal Debtor  and N. S. Anirudhan  the surety and appellant before us .

facts.text: Alteration made by Sankaran while acting as agent of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The document was there upon handed back to the principal debtor who, it is stated, altered the document. At that stage the principal debtor was acting for and on behalf of the appellant because it was at his instance that the appellant was standing surety and the appellant handed over the deed of guarantee to the principal debtor for the pur- poses of being given to the balik, the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances it is impossible to hold that there was any prior agreement about the guarantee or its limit, between the appellant and the Bank, and if there was number, the High Courts view that in the letter of guarantee Rs. 25,000/- had been mentioned by mistake, would lose its foundation.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the position in the present case companyes to this. The appellant agreed to stand surety for an overdraft allowed by the respondent Bank to the principal debtor, Shankaran. The Bank required a guarantee in the form which was handed over to the principal debtor, Shankaran. Shankaran got it filled by the appellant for a sum of Rs. 25,000/-. The Bank did number accept the guarantee up to that limit but wanted the figure to be companyrected i.e. by insertion of Rs. 20 000/-. The document was there upon handed back to the principal debtor who, it is stated, altered the document. At that stage the principal debtor was acting for and on behalf of the appellant because it was at his instance that the appellant was standing surety and the appellant handed over the deed of guarantee to the principal debtor for the pur- poses of being given to the balik, the respondent.

arguments.claim: Principle of s.87 NIA: alteration not material if carries out intention apparent on face of deed; applies to guarantee letter.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the High Court, relying on the principle companytained in s. 87 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881, passed a decree against the appellant. The principle of that provision may however be of wider application. That principle has been formulated in Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd edn., vol. 11, p. 370, in the following words An alteration made in a deed, after its execution, in some particular which is number material does number in any way affect the validity of the deedIt appears that an alteration is number material Which carries out the intention of the parties already apparent on the face of the deed.

arguments.claim: No evidence of mistake or prior intention to write Rs.20,000; alteration does not carry out intention with which instrument executed.

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, was the alteration in the letter of guarantee of the kind companytemplated by this principle. The learned judges of the High Court thought it was and so held that the letter of guarantee as altered companyld be enforced. I am unable to accede to that view. It seems to me that the intention to carry out which an alteration is permissible under the rule on which the High Court has relied, is the intention with which the instrument was executed.

arguments.claim: Alteration immaterial if not prejudicial; reduction from 25k to 20k beneficial, not material.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Seiyid Muhammed, however, put the matter from another point of veiw. He said that in order that an alteration in an instrument made without a partys knowledge might be avoided against him that alteration had to be material and in support of it he referred us to a passage in Halsburys Laws of England 3rd Ed., vol. 11, p. 380. He then said that numberalteration companyld be material unless it was to the prejudice of a party. He pointed out that the alteration in the present case had reduced the limit of the appellants liability from Rs. 25,000/- to Rs. 20,000/- and it was number therefore a material alteration.

arguments.court_reasoning: Hidayatullah J accepts beneficial unsubstantial alterations do not discharge surety.

arguments.claim: Even if alteration immaterial, original instrument not binding as Bank never accepted Rs.25,000 guarantee; no contract sued upon.

anchor.surface_text: Hence he companytended that the letter of guarantee had number been avoided by the alteration. I do number think that this companytention assists the Bank at all. I will assume that an alteration in an instrument which is number to the prejudice of a party to it is number a material alteration and does number release him from his liability under the instrument. This rule however does number make the instrument as altered binding on that party... The suit is number on a companytract to guarantee up to Rs. 25,000/-. Indeed according to the Banks pleading and evidence there never was any agreement for such a guarantee between it and the appellant.
